title: Crystal Cruises expands presence on the seas, rivers — and in...
text:
Luxury line Crystal Cruises is kicking it up a notch. Make that several notches.
Over the next three years, the cruise line will add several vessels to its two-ship fleet — along with its own Boeing 787 Dreamliner aircraft.
The launch of the 62-guest Crystal Esprit in December marks the beginning of a three-year major expansion program for Crystal Cruises. (Rendering contributed by Crystal Cruises). The excitement starts with the launch of the 62-guest Crystal Esprit in December, the first ship in the Crystal Yacht Cruises program. The all-suite yacht will feature a two-passenger submarine, four 10-passenger Zodiac boats for special excursions, and a 12-passenger Wider 32-foot super yacht tender for special adventures.
This, in addition to water skis, wake boards, kayaks and equipment for fishing, snorkeling and scuba diving.
Cruisers will have a long way to travel to experience Crystal Esprit, which will spend the next couple years in the Seychelles Islands, Dubai and the Adriatic Coast.
A rendering of the marina area of Crystal Esprit, which will offer a two-passenger submarine along with all types of water sports equipment. (Contributed by Crystal Cruises) Crystal River Cruises will launch in the spring of 2017, though the line did not announce too many details beyond promising six-star service, world-class dining and spacious suites.
Also making its debut in 2017 will be Crystal Luxury Air. No worries about not getting enough leg room. This aircraft, designed for 300 passengers, will fly only 60 guests in fully reclining, business class seats.
Itineraries will be about 28 days long, visiting up to a dozen remote and/or sought-after locales, the cruise line said. Accommodations will be at top-rated hotels and resorts, with cuisine prepared by celebrity chefs.
Kate McCue takes the helm of Celebrity Summit in August as the first American female captain. (Contributed by Celebrity Cruises) Sounds like a cruise — without the water part.
In late 2018, the Crystal Exclusive Class of ships is expected to launch with the first of three new ships. Shipbuilder Lloyd Werft in Germany will build the polar ice class vessels. The all-suite, all-balcony ships will accommodate 1,000 guests
Suites on the new ships will be a minimum of 400 square feet, and the crew-to-guest ration will be one-to-one.
Chris Hondros Former CBS Evening News anchor Dan Rather will be aboard Seabourn Odyssey as part of a lecture series hosted by the cruise line. (Photo by Chris Hondros/Getty Images) Bonus: The new ships will include Crystal Residences, 48 unique “homes” with their own private restaurant and other facilities. The residences — no purchase prices announced yet — will range from 600 square feet to more than 4,000.
Learn more about the cruise line’s plans at www.crystalthenextchapter.com.
AT THE HELM
Celebrity Cruises has named Kate McCue the cruise industry’s first American female captain.
She’ll be at the helm of the 2,158-guest Celebrity Summit, sailing from the Cape Liberty Cruise Port in New Jersey to Bermuda, beginning in August.
The 37-year-old McCue is a graduate of California State University’s California Maritime Academy and most recently served as Master Mariner with Royal Caribbean International.
CELEBRITIES ON BOARD
Imagine bumping into Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak poolside, or rubbing elbows with journalist Dan Rather while enjoying dinner.
The two are among the lecturers for Seabourn Conversations, an onboard enrichment program featuring adventurers, artists, historians and the business elite sharing tales of success and personal insights. Lecturers also may share meals, adventures ashore and casual chats with guests throughout the voyage.
Wozniak, who was awarded the National Medal of Technology by President Ronald Reagan in 1985 and inducted into the Inventors Hall of Fame in 2000, will participate in the program on Seabourn Odyssey’s Holiday Panama Canal cruise, which departs Fort Lauderdale on Dec. 15 and arrives in Los Angeles on Jan. 4.
Rather will be aboard during part of Seabourn Odyssey’s 20-day Panama Canal cruise, which leaves from Los Angeles March 21 and sails to Fort Lauderdale. Rather retired in 2005 after 24 years at helm of CBS Evening News.
See the whole lineup of Seabourn Conversations lecturers at www.seabourn.com , under the Life Onboard menu item.
